content:
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Product Manager] --> B[UX Designer]
    B --> C[Lead Frontend Developer]
    C --> D[Lead Backend Developer]

    subgraph UI/UX
        A --> E[New Button]
        E --> F[Modal (Pop-up)]
        F --> G[Form with fields: Phone to Request, Phone to Exchange, Reason for Request (Optional), Submit Request, Cancel buttons]
        F --> H[Confirmation Message]
    end

    subgraph Backend Logic
        F --> I[API Endpoint (POST /api/phone-swaps)]
        I --> J[Database Table: Swap Requests]
        J --> K[Validation to ensure user ownership of offered phone in exchange]
    end

    A --> L[Jira Ticket with User Story and Acceptance Criteria]
```
meeting_notes:
Phone Swap Request Feature
Date: October 14, 2025
Attendees: Product Manager, UX Designer, Lead Frontend Developer, Lead Backend Developer
Objective: Define the requirements and implementation plan for the new phone swap request feature.

Background
Users currently lack a formal way to request an exchange of their current phone for another one available in our inventory. This new feature aims to create a streamlined, in-app workflow to manage these requests efficiently.

Feature Overview
The team agreed on the following user story: "As a user, I want to request a phone from the available list and offer one of my current phones in exchange, so I can easily manage my device swaps."

The feature will be implemented as a modal pop-up on the main phone list page.

Implementation Details
Frontend (UI/UX)
A new button, labeled "Request Phone Swap," will be added to the main phone page.

Clicking this button will trigger a modal (pop-up) that overlays the current view.

The modal will contain a form with the following fields:

Phone to Request: A dropdown list populated with all available phones from the main list.

Phone to Exchange: A dropdown list showing only the phones currently owned by the logged-in user.

Reason for Request (Optional): A text area for any additional comments.

Actions: "Submit Request" and "Cancel" buttons.

Upon successful submission, the modal will close, and a confirmation message will be displayed.

Backend (Logic)
A new API endpoint (POST /api/phone-swaps) will be created to handle form submissions.

A new table will be created in the database to store swap requests. It will include columns for the requester's ID, the requested phone, the offered phone, a status (defaulting to 'Pending'), and the comment.

Backend validation will ensure that the user making the request is the actual owner of the phone being offered in exchange.

Action Items
UX Team: Create a wireframe of the modal and form by EOD, October 17.

Backend Team: Develop the new API endpoint and database schema. Target completion: October 21.

Frontend Team: Build the "Request Phone Swap" button and the basic modal structure. Begin implementation once wireframes are approved.

Product Manager: Create the formal Jira ticket with the defined user story and acceptance criteria.

meeting_notes:
Phone Swap Request Feature
Date: October 14, 2025
Attendees: Product Manager, UX Designer, Lead Frontend Developer, Lead Backend Developer
Objective: Define the requirements and implementation plan for the new phone swap request feature.

Background
Users currently lack a formal way to request an exchange of their current phone for another one available in our inventory. This new feature aims to create a streamlined, in-app workflow to manage these requests efficiently.

Feature Overview
The team agreed on the following user story: "As a user, I want to request a phone from the available list and offer one of my current phones in exchange, so I can easily manage my device swaps."

The feature will be implemented as a modal pop-up on the main phone list page.

Implementation Details
Frontend (UI/UX)
A new button, labeled "Request Phone Swap," will be added to the main phone page.

Clicking this button will trigger a modal (pop-up) that overlays the current view.

The modal will contain a form with the following fields:

Phone to Request: A dropdown list populated with all available phones from the main list.

Phone to Exchange: A dropdown list showing only the phones currently owned by the logged-in user.

Reason for Request (Optional): A text area for any additional comments.

Actions: "Submit Request" and "Cancel" buttons.

Upon successful submission, the modal will close, and a confirmation message will be displayed.

Backend (Logic)
A new API endpoint (POST /api/phone-swaps) will be created to handle form submissions.

A new table will be created in the database to store swap requests. It will include columns for the requester's ID, the requested phone, the offered phone, a status (defaulting to 'Pending'), and the comment.

Backend validation will ensure that the user making the request is the actual owner of the phone being offered in exchange.

Action Items
UX Team: Create a wireframe of the modal and form by EOD, October 17.

Backend Team: Develop the new API endpoint and database schema. Target completion: October 21.

Frontend Team: Build the "Request Phone Swap" button and the basic modal structure. Begin implementation once wireframes are approved.

Product Manager: Create the formal Jira ticket with the defined user story and acceptance criteria.

content:
Here's a comprehensive Mermaid ERD (Entity-Relationship Diagram) based on the requirements:

```mermaid
erDiagram
  User ||--o{ Phone: owns
  Phone ||--|{ SwapRequest: contains
  SwapRequest }|--> ReasonForRequest : has
  SwapRequest }|--> Status : has

classDef phone green fill, stroke;
classDef swapRequest blue fill, stroke;
classDef reasonForRequest orange fill, stroke;
classDef status red fill, stroke;

class Phone {
  - id string
  - ownerId string
  - modelName string
}

class SwapRequest {
  - id string
  - requestId string references User(id)
  - requestedPhoneId string references Phone(id)
  - offeredPhoneId string references Phone(id)
  - comment text
  - status Status default "Pending"
}

class ReasonForRequest {
  - id string
  - requestSwapRequestId string references SwapRequest(id)
  - reason text
}

class Status {
  - id string
  - name string
  - description text
}
```

This ERD defines the following entities:

1. **User**: represents a user who owns phones.
2. **Phone**: represents a phone that can be requested or offered in exchange.
3. **SwapRequest**: represents a request to swap one phone for another. It has relationships with:
	* **ReasonForRequest**: an optional reason for the request (if provided).
	* **Status**: the status of the request (defaulting to "Pending").
4. **ReasonForRequest**: an entity that stores the reason for a swap request.
5. **Status**: an enumeration of possible statuses for a swap request.

The relationships between entities are as follows:

1. A user owns multiple phones (one-to-many).
2. A phone can be requested or offered in exchange (many-to-many).
3. A swap request is associated with one reason and one status.
4. A status applies to multiple swap requests.

This ERD captures the essential relationships and entities required for implementing the Phone Swap Request feature.

Here's a comprehensive Mermaid ERD (Entity-Relationship Diagram) based on the requirements:

```mermaid
erDiagram
  User ||--o{ Phone: owns
  Phone ||--|{ SwapRequest: contains
  SwapRequest }|--> ReasonForRequest : has
  SwapRequest }|--> Status : has

classDef phone green fill, stroke;
classDef swapRequest blue fill, stroke;
classDef reasonForRequest orange fill, stroke;
classDef status red fill, stroke;

class Phone {
  - id string
  - ownerId string

Frontend (UI/UX)

content:
Here's a comprehensive Mermaid ERD (Entity-Relationship Diagram) for the Phone Swap Request feature:

```mermaid
erDiagram
  USER ||--o{ PHONE : owns
  PHONE ||--|{ SWAP_REQUEST : offered_in_exchange
  PHONE ||--|{ AVAIL_PHONE : requested_phone
  SWAP_REQUEST ||--|{ COMMENT : reason_for_request

  CLASS USER {
    - id (primary key)
    - email
  }

  CLASS PHONE {
    - id (primary key)
    - name
    - description
    - user_id (foreign key referencing the USER table)
  }

  CLASS SWAP_REQUEST {
    - id (primary key)
    - user_id (foreign key referencing the USER table)
    - requested_phone_id (foreign key referencing the PHONE table)
    - offered_phone_id (foreign key referencing the PHONE table)
    - status (default: 'Pending')
    - comment
  }

  CLASS AVAIL_PHONE {
    - id (primary key)
    - name
    - description
  }

  CLASS COMMENT {
    - id (primary key)
    - text
    - swap_request_id (foreign key referencing the SWAP_REQUEST table)
  }
```

This ERD represents the relationships between the entities involved in the Phone Swap Request feature:

1. A user owns one or more phones.
2. Each phone has a unique ID and is offered in exchange for another phone through a swap request.
3. The requested phone and the offered phone are both instances of the PHONE entity.
4. A swap request belongs to a specific user and includes information about the requested phone, the offered phone, and any additional comments.
5. Comments are associated with each swap request.

This ERD should provide a solid foundation for designing the database schema and implementing the Phone Swap Request feature.

content:
**Mermaid Flowchart for Phone Swap Request Feature**

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[User clicks "Request Phone Swap" button] -->|Triggers modal popup| B[Modal with form]
    B -->|Contains fields: Phone to Request, Phone to Exchange, Reason for Request (Optional), Actions| C[Form submission]
    C -->|Validates user's ownership of offered phone| D[Backend validation]
    D -->|Successful submission| E[Confirmation message displayed]
    E -->|Modal closes| F[User sees confirmation message]
    C -->|Invalid submission| G[Error message displayed]
    G -->|Modal stays open until corrected| H[Form resubmission]
```

**Explanation**

1. The user clicks the "Request Phone Swap" button, triggering a modal popup to appear.
2. The modal contains a form with three fields: Phone to Request (dropdown list of available phones), Phone to Exchange (dropdown list of phones owned by the logged-in user), and Reason for Request (optional text area).
3. When the user submits the form, the backend validation checks if the user is the actual owner of the phone being offered in exchange.
4. If the submission is successful, a confirmation message is displayed, and the modal closes.
5. If the submission is invalid (e.g., the user is not the owner of the offered phone), an error message is displayed, and the modal stays open until the issue is corrected.

**Notes**

* The wireframe for the modal and form should be created by EOD October 17 as per the action item.
* The new API endpoint (POST /api/phone-swaps) will handle form submissions.
* A new table will be created in the database to store swap requests, including columns for the requester's ID, requested phone, offered phone, status, and comment.

**Validation**

The Mermaid flowchart ensures that all possible paths are accounted for, from the user clicking the "Request Phone Swap" button to the successful or unsuccessful submission of the form. The validation process checks if the user is the actual owner of the phone being offered in exchange, preventing potential issues with swap requests.

Phone to Request: A dropdown list populated with all available phones from the main list.

Phone to Exchange: A dropdown list showing only the phones currently owned by the logged-in user.

Reason for Request (Optional): A text area for any additional comments.

Actions: "Submit Request" and "Cancel" buttons.

Upon successful submission, the modal will close, and a confirmation message will be displayed.

Backend (Logic)
A new API endpoint (POST /api/phone-swaps) will be created to handle form submissions.

A new table will be created in the database to store swap requests. It will include columns for the requester's ID, the requested phone, the offered phone, a status (defaulting to 'Pending'), and the comment.

Backend validation will ensure that the user making the request is the actual owner of the phone being offered in exchange.

Action Items
UX Team: Create a wireframe of the modal and form by EOD, October 17.

Backend Team: Develop the new API endpoint and database schema. Target completion: October 21.

Frontend Team: Build the "Request Phone Swap" button and the basic modal structure. Begin implementation once wireframes are approved.

Product Manager: Create the formal Jira ticket with the defined user story and acceptance criteria.

content:
**Mermaid Flowchart for Phone Swap Request Feature**

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[User clicks "Request Phone Swap" button] -->|Triggers modal popup| B[Modal with form]
    B -->|Contains fields: Phone to Request, Phone to Exchange, Reason for Request (Optional), Actions| C[Form submission]
    C -->|Validates user's ownership of offered phone| D[Backend validation]
    D -->|Successful submission| E[Confirmation message displayed]
    E -->|Modal closes| F[User sees confirmation message]
    C -->|Invalid submission| G[Error message displayed]
    G -->|Modal stays open until corrected| H[Form resubmission]
```

**Explanation**

1. The user clicks the "Request Phone Swap" button, triggering a modal popup to appear.
2. The modal contains a form with three fields: Phone to Request (dropdown list of available phones), Phone to Exchange (dropdown list of phones owned by the logged-in user), and Reason for Request (optional text area).
3. When the user submits the form, the backend validation checks if the user is the actual owner of the phone being offered in exchange.
4. If the submission is successful, a confirmation message is displayed, and the modal closes.
5. If the submission is invalid (e.g., the user is not the owner of the offered phone), an error message is displayed, and the modal stays open until the issue is corrected.

**Notes**

* The wireframe for the modal and form should be created by EOD October 17 as per the action item.
* The new API endpoint (POST /api/phone-swaps) will handle form submissions.
* A new table will be created in the database to store swap requests, including columns for the requester's ID, requested phone, offered phone, status, and comment.

**Validation**

The Mermaid flowchart ensures that all possible paths are accounted for, from the user clicking the "Request Phone Swap" button to the successful or unsuccessful submission of the form. The validation process checks if the user is the actual owner of the phone being offered in exchange, preventing potential issues with swap requests.

Action Items

content:
**Mermaid ERD for Phone Swap Request Feature**

```mermaid
erDiagram
  CUSTOMER ||--o{ PHONE_SWAP_REQUEST : has
  PHONE_SWAP_REQUEST ||--|{ PHONE : requested
  PHONE_SWAP_REQUEST ||--|{ PHONE : offered
  CUSTOMER }|..|{ PHONE : owns

  TABLE PHONE_SWAP_REQUEST (
    id int primary key,
    requester_id int references CUSTOMER(id),
    requested_phone_id int references PHONE(id),
    offered_phone_id int references PHONE(id),
    status varchar(10) default 'Pending',
    comment text
  )

  TABLE PHONE (
    id int primary key,
    customer_id int references CUSTOMER(id)
  )
```

**Explanation**

This ERD diagram represents the entities and relationships involved in the Phone Swap Request feature. The main entities are:

* `CUSTOMER`: represents a user who can request a phone swap.
* `PHONE_SWAP_REQUEST`: represents a request to exchange one phone for another.
* `PHONE`: represents a phone that can be requested or offered as part of a swap.

The relationships between these entities are:

* A customer (`CUSTOMER`) has many phone swap requests (`PHONE_SWAP_REQUEST`).
* A phone swap request (`PHONE_SWAP_REQUEST`) is related to two phones: the one being requested (`requested_phone`) and the one being offered in exchange (`offered_phone`).
* A customer (`CUSTOMER`) owns many phones (`PHONE`).

The `PHONE_SWAP_REQUEST` table has the following columns:

* `id`: a unique identifier for each request.
* `requester_id`: the ID of the customer making the request, referencing the `CUSTOMER` table.
* `requested_phone_id`: the ID of the phone being requested, referencing the `PHONE` table.
* `offered_phone_id`: the ID of the phone being offered in exchange, referencing the `PHONE` table.
* `status`: the status of the request (defaulting to 'Pending').
* `comment`: any additional comments provided by the customer.

The `PHONE` table has the following columns:

* `id`: a unique identifier for each phone.
* `customer_id`: the ID of the customer who owns the phone, referencing the `CUSTOMER` table.

This ERD diagram captures the key entities and relationships involved in the Phone Swap Request feature, ensuring that the data is properly structured to support the required functionality.

content:
Here is a comprehensive Mermaid ERD (Entity-Relationship Diagram) for the Phone Swap Request Feature:

```mermaid
erDiagram
  USER ||--o{ PHONE : owns
  PHONE ||--|{ SWAP_REQUEST : requested_in_exchange
  SWAP_REQUEST ||--|{ PHONE : offered_in_exchange

  class USER {
    - id (primary key)
    - username
  }

  class PHONE {
    - id (primary key)
    - name
    - description
    - available boolean
    - user_id (foreign key references USER(id))
  }

  class SWAP_REQUEST {
    - id (primary key)
    - requester_id (foreign key references USER(id))
    - requested_phone_id (foreign key references PHONE(id))
    - offered_phone_id (foreign key references PHONE(id))
    - status (default 'Pending', possible values: ['Pending', 'Approved', 'Denied'])
    - comment (text area input)
  }
```

This ERD captures the entities and relationships involved in the Phone Swap Request Feature:

1. **USER**: Represents the users of the system, with a unique ID and username.
2. **PHONE**: Represents the phones available for swap, with a unique ID, name, description, availability status, and foreign key referencing the user who owns it.
3. **SWAP_REQUEST**: Represents the phone swap requests made by users, with a unique ID, foreign keys referencing the requester's user ID, requested phone ID, and offered phone ID, as well as a status (default 'Pending') and comment.

The relationships between these entities are:

* A user can own multiple phones (one-to-many).
* A phone can be requested for swap by multiple users (many-to-many).
* A swap request is made by one user and involves two phones (many-to-one).

This ERD provides a clear visual representation of the data model, which can help guide the implementation of the feature.
